The sentence contains an Event, which is the main event of the individual feeling frustrated and hopeless about the meaninglessness of life.
Post:
"I'm so tired of feeling like nothing I do matters. It's like no matter how hard I try, I'm just stuck in this rut and can't seem to break free."

This post attributes the cause of the individual's frustration and hopelessness to their own inherent flaws or shortcomings, implying that they are naturally prone to failure or struggling. It is an example of a stable attributional style because it suggests that the cause of the event (the individual's feelings of meaninglessness) is chronic and long-lasting, rather than temporary or situational.

Event: Moving into a new flat and dealing with the anxiety and stress of doing so without proper support from parents.
Post:
"I'm feeling overwhelmed with anxiety and stress as I move into my new flat. It's like I'm stuck in a never-ending cycle of uncertainty and self-doubt. I wish my parents were here to support me, but I guess I'm just not cut out for this whole independence thing."

This post exhibits a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the stress and anxiety to the individual's inherent inability to handle the situation, rather than external factors such as lack of support from parents. It implies that the individual is naturally prone to feeling overwhelmed and uncertain, and that this is a chronic problem that they will always face.

Post:
"I'm stuck in a dead-end job that I hate, but at least it pays the bills. Unfortunately, the stress is taking a toll on my mental health and I can't say I'm really enjoying life right now."

This post displays a stable attributional style because it attributes the cause of the negative outcome (stress and lack of enjoyment) to a stable factor (the job itself, which is perceived as dead-end and hated). It implies that the speaker is naturally unlucky or ill-suited for certain types of work, rather than considering other factors such as their own actions or external circumstances.
